items.content_html:
Fixes #15622

There are external links to /en-US/docs/Using_web_workers. We don't have a redirect to this moved page.

This PR adds one.

yarn content add-redirect /en-US/docs/Using_web_workers /en-US/docs/Web/API/Web_Workers_API/Using_web_workers
items.title: Add redirect to Using web workers

items.content_html:
Summary

  • Fix a link in tabs.onUpdated() page
  • Explain favIconUrl behavior when a page has no favicon

Motivation

Makes clear to developers what to expect of favIconUrl property in both changeInfo parameter of the tabs.onUpdated callback and tabs.Tab, so that they can take into account when a tab loses its favicon (e.g. when navigating from a page that has a favicon to one that doesn’t).

Supporting details

https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1450384#c8

Related issues

Fix #4324

items.content_html:
Summary

One-word change at line 81: "... construct different absolute URLs ..." to "... construct different relative URLs ...".

Motivation

I was reading through the docs and this seemed odd. The instructions say to specify an absolute URL and warn that if you specify a relative URL, "different browsers may construct different absolute URLs"? I think it's supposed to be "different browsers may construct different relative URLs", based on the wording and context alone.

I don't know if browsers construct different absolute URLs or relative URLs, so I might be wrong! It just seems weird from a linguistic perspective.

Supporting details

It seems that the cbe151a initial commit already had this issue.

Related issues

Unknown.

Metadata

  • Adds a new document
  • Rewrites (or significantly expands) a document
  • Fixes a typo, bug, or other error
items.title: Changed `different absolute` to `different relative`

items.content_html:
Summary

Instead of using emoji as an example of an explicitly-requested collation type, use zhuyin instead.

Motivation

The emoji collation type is intended for charts and emoji pickers and that it combines with a language like English is incidental and works only because English is an alias for the root collation. Notably, it doesn't combine with languages that aren't aliases for the root.

The non-default collation types that have the most present-day use case relevance are probably zhuyin for Traditional Chinese and phonebk for German and of these, phonebooks are arguably more special-casey. Therefore, using zhuyin as the example.

Supporting details

tc39/proposal-intl-locale-info#33 (comment)

Related issues

Metadata

  • Adds a new document
  • Rewrites (or significantly expands) a document
  • Fixes a typo, bug, or other error
items.title: Avoid using emoji as a collation example

items.content_html:
Summary

Document what languages various collation types apply to (at present). Document which ones Chrome and Edge exclude. (I didn't test if there are other Chromium-based browsers that undo the exclusions.) Give advice against using types that are unavailable, already defaults, or problematic in the case of unusual naming for Swedish.

Motivation

My main motivation is preparation for Swedish renaming and preparation for aligning Firefox with the exclusions that Chrome already makes.

Supporting details

The language applicability comes from searching CLDR source.

Chrome and Edge exclusions can be seen in the source and verified by a demo.

Related issues

Metadata

  • Rewrites (or significantly expands) a document
  • Fixes a typo, bug, or other error
items.title: Add more information about collation types

The stack trace is added (if it is) to the object returned by the constructor, not when the object is thrown. This was incorrect in a number of places. Fixed now.

Thanks very much @eqrion

items.content_html:
** do not merge until all Manifest V3 content is ready **

Summary

Changes to the manifest keys for Manifest V3 support in the developer preview, including:

  • update to the keys list on the overview page to add details of supported manifest versions
  • addition of a "Manifest version" line into the overview table of every manifest key page
  • addition of the action key (as a copy of the browser_action key) with cross-reference information between the two
  • update to favicon_url of the chrome_settings_overrides manifest key that a local URL must be provided in MV3.

Metadata

This PR…

items.title: MV3 Manifest keys updates

items.content_html:
Summary

Drop 0 from fractionalSecondDigits values spec.
Because it is incorrect with Intl API Spec.

Motivation

Actually web browsers does not implement to allow 0 for fractionalSecondDigits, and throws RangeError when using fractionalSecondDigits: 0.
I confirmed with Chrome v101, Safari v15.4, Firefox v99 and Node.js v16,v17.

Supporting details

fractionalSecondDigits does not allow 0 in ECMAScript® 2021 Internationalization API Specification.
https://402.ecma-international.org/8.0/#sec-datetimeformat-abstracts

Related issues

tc39/ecma402#590

Metadata

  • Adds a new document
  • Rewrites (or significantly expands) a document
  • Fixes a typo, bug, or other error
items.title: Drop `0` from fractionalSecondDigits values spec.

items.content_html:
Summary

Remove content about Error.prototype.toSource, Error.prototype.description, and Error.prototype.number (non-standard and obsolete).

Motivation

Remove non-standard obsolete attributes in accordance with BCD guideline "Removal of irrelevant features".

Supporting details

  1. Error.prototype.toSource was removed from Firefox (as shown in BCD and confirmed by testing) and Firefox Android (as tested). Tested with jsconsole.com and the folloqing:
    • 'toString' in Error.prototype returns true
    • 'toSource' in Error.prototype returns false
  2. Error.prototype.description and Error.prototype.number are long gone, do not even show up in IE mode in Edge and IE 11. Error.prototype.description was replaced with standard Error.prototype.message which was released in IE 6 (according to BCD). Error.prototype.number usage can be somewhat replaced by Error.prototype.name which was also released in IE 6 (according to BCD).

Related issues

mdn/browser-compat-data#16134

Metadata

  • Adds a new document
  • Rewrites (or significantly expands) a document
  • Fixes a typo, bug, or other error
items.title: Remove obsolete attributes of Error

items.content_html:
Summary

made "Test your skills!" pages of the Learn/HTML and Learn/CSS modules more consistent:

  • add tags where they where missing / incomplete
  • add missing sidebar in the background and borders skill test
  • adapt introduction sentences
  • adapt note box (under the introduction sentences) - the "However" part.
  • adapt headings to fit the articles title and use numbers instead of written out numbers (i thought this is easier to read and also in the discourse forum easier and clearer to handle)
  • adapt "Assessment or further help" sections to be uniform
  • adapt the code example (interactive editor) sentences and "boxes"

Motivation

to keep things consistent - i have done this "consistency changes" now a few times in prs and it was always appreciated.

i made a few decisions based on how most test your skills pages (including the ones for Learn/JavaScript...) were structured and written (e.g. the boxes below the interactive editros were written most of the time in the "shorter way", but not for the Learn/CSS part)

items.title: Make Test your skills pages consistent
